Additional Info: Minnesota Building and Construction Trades Council
content:
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 April 16, 2025  
 
The Honorable Megan McKenzie  
Office of Administrative Hearings  
600 N. Robert Street  
Saint Paul, MN 55164  
 
Mr. Will Seuffert  
Executive Secretary  
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
121 7th Place East, Suite 350  
St. Paul, MN 55101    
RE: Comments in the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners (Docket 24 -198)  
 
Judge McKenzie and Mr. Seuffert,  
 On behalf of the 70,000 skilled construction workers represented by the unions affiliated with 
the Minnesota Building and Construction Trades Council, I am writing to share our support for 
the proposed purchase of ALLETE, Inc. by infrastructure investment funds managed by the 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners. We support the transaction because we believe it is the best path for Minnesota Power to secure the capital 
needed to build a safe, reliable and increasingly carb on-free grid using local union labor.  
 
The men and women represented by the Minnesota Building Trades have counted on 
Minnesota Power to provide affordable, reliable power and economic opportunity in Northeast 
Minnesota for more than 100 years. During that time, the company’s ownership structur e has 
changed, but the commitment to customers and union workers has not.  
 
The first question Minnesota Building Trades and our affiliated unions asked ourselves after the 
announcement was how a utility owned by a couple of large infrastructure fund investors might 
differ from one owned by Wall Street stockholders. Based on our i nitial review of the proposal 
and our experience with the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission, we came to the conclusion 
that the sale would have no impact on the way Minnesota Power operates on a day -to-day 
basis, while greatly strengthening the utility ’s capacity to attract capital and support badly -
needed economic growth in its service territory.  
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 Since that time, Minnesota Building Trades unions and members have participated in either the 
contested case proceedings or the public hearings, and nothing any of them have seen or heard 
to date has weakened our conclusion that the sale is in the best interest of customers and 
workers. While we know that change can be scary, nothing about the transaction affects the ability of the Public Utilities Commission to set rates and allowed capital structures, or to 
approve or deny investment on the front end or r ate and rider recovery on the back end. The 
controls in place after the transaction will be the same as those that exist today, as will the financial incentive to meet the expectations and requirements established by the Legislature 
and Public Utilities Co mmission.  
 
It’s no secret why ALLETE pursued a private acquisition after more than seven decades as a 
publicly -traded company. In 2023, the State of Minnesota required every utility serving 
Minnesota customers to achieve 100% carbon -free power by 2050. For Minnesota Power, 
which relies heavily on coal- fired power despite the utility’s leadership in renewable 
generation, meeting that mandate means unprecedented investment in transmission, 
renewable generation, batteries and other low - and zero -carbon technology. The sc ale of 
needed investment is far beyond anything ALLETE has done in the past or is capable of doing as a stand -alone company  
 
The elected leaders of Minnesota’s Building Trades unions understand the challenge, because 
they sit on boards that manage hundreds of billions of dollars in pension fund assets and are 
affiliated with international unions that collectively invest more than $500 billion in stocks, bonds, infrastructure, real estate and over investment vehicles. We recognize that a $6 billion 
company seeking an additional $5 billion in capital over just five years looks like a potentially 
risky proposition even before considering Minnesota Power’s unique exposure to risks 
associated with ebb and flow of mining activity.  
 
The Minnesota Building Trades supported Minnesota’s 100% clean energy when it passed in 
2023, despite the fact that achieving the mandate will impact the livelihood of members who 
maintain coal -fired power plants and other legacy infrastructure. For this r eason, it has been 
disappointing to see a number of organizations and institutions that say they support climate 
progress oppose the transaction without providing any realistic alternative for financing 
Minnesota Power’s clean energy transition.  
 
We are especially troubled by claims that the utility could meet the need for additional capital 
by relying more on customers, third -party providers or other utilities as suggested by the  
 
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 Department of Commerce, Office of the Attorney General and others. While some have tried to 
stir up opposition to the acquisition by inaccurately describing the transfer of a utility from one  
set of private investors to another as “privatization,”
1 the real threat of deregulation and 
privatization comes from the outsourcing of the utility’s obligation to serve to third parties that 
are not fully under the control and oversight of the Public Utilities Commission.  
 
Minnesota Power employs all of the tools suggested by parties concerned about the transaction 
today to provide the Public Utilities Commission with a full set of options, and to provide 
customers with the best value. Minnesota Power regularly solicits thir d-party bids for energy 
generation, encourages residential customers to install rooftop solar and partners with utilities 
like Great River Energy to build and finance transmission projects. But in each case the utility’s 
capability of delivering these projects on its own helps to ensure that the priorities of the 
utility’s customers are not subordinated to the interests of third parties.  
 
Minnesota Power has already experienced the limitations of even modest levels of reliance on 
third parties. The utility struggled for years to develop a demand response product that was 
acceptable to both large industrial customers and the Public Utilities  Commission due to the 
cost of compensation that customers expected in exchange for curtailing their demand.  
 
Similarly, Minnesota Power saw its plan for development of solar generation in the service 
territory delayed when the low -bidder Cypress Creek failed to deliver the 10 MW Blanchard 
Solar project because the company was unable to secure site control. The ut ility’s solar 
requirement was only met when Minnesota Power filed a 20 MW self- build proposal, and we 
expect the Commission to shortly approve an additional 200 MW of self- built solar in Cohasset 
and Royalton as the best option to meet the need identified in the current Integrated Resource Plan.  
 
If Minnesota Power is unable to secure adequate capital to continue proposing utility -financed 
projects or to do so cost -effectively, customers and the public interest will suffer in important 
ways. The potential consequences of a capital shortage are pote ntially severe. Capital shortfalls 
could create deployment delays that could threaten the utility’s ability to meet requirements, 
maintain reliability and/or take advantage of favorable market conditions and avoid 
unfavorable conditions. Further capital shortfalls will almost certainly result in higher costs for 
customers by reducing competition and giving third parties more leverage to extract premiums 
in cases where the utility could have provided a more cost -effective option.  
 
1 https://curemn.org/blog/take -the-power -back/   
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 Workers will also suffer from capital constraints, first, as a result of project cancellations and 
delays; and second, because capital shortfalls will limit Minnesota Power’s ability to set and  
enforce requirements that advance the workers’ interests and the state’s values. A decade ago, 
large wind and solar energy projects built to serve Minnesota utilities created very few jobs for 
union or local workers, as documented by North Star Policy Inst itute and Local Jobs North 
because the third- party developers responsible for construction hired contractors that relied 
heavily on non -union out- of-state workforce.
2  
 
Today, similar projects are creating hundreds of jobs for union and local workforce, in large part 
because utilities like Xcel Energy and Minnesota Power began to simultaneously pursue more 
self-build projects, and to make use of local and/or union labor a  requirement for Power 
Purchase Agreement providers that were previously reluctant to make any such commitments. Neither utility could have moved the market without having the option of building their own projects if third -party providers balked. The same is true for efforts to increase participation of 
people of color, women and veterans in the workforce and as vendors, which have made much greater strides through utility -owned than through third -party -owned projects.  
 
The dynamic is even worse for customer- owned generation, where the state’s values in the 
area of fair compensation, respect for workers’ rights, and workforce inclusion play little or no 
role, because neither the utility nor the Public Utilities Commission  can easily tell customers 
how to build their own projects. As a result, industries such as rooftop solar installation are dominated by low -wage work and lack the sort of inclusive career pathways adopted by 
Building Trades unions. Given the poor economies  of scale associated with most distributed 
generation projects, increasing Minnesota Power’s reliance on them would push up rates, transfer wealth from lower to higher -income customers best able to take advantage of these 
programs, and exchange high -qualit y jobs on utility -scale projects for lower- quality jobs on 
distributed projects.  
 
It is clear to us that approval of the proposed transaction will bring significant benefits to 
Minnesota Building Trades members in the form of more and lower- cost investments in job -
creating projects, coupled with preservation of the utility’s ability to provide the capital needed 
to provide safe, reliable, affordable, and increasingly clean power. On the other hand, a 
decision to deny approval could have damaging consequences, destroying job opportunities on  
 
 
2 https://northstarpolicy.org/catching- the-wind -the-impact -of-local -vs-non-local -hiring- practices -on-construction -
of-minnesota -wind -farms/ ; https://www.localjobsnorth.org/reports   
 
Dan McConnell , President         •  DON MULLIN , Secretary  Treasurer         •  TOM DICKLICH , Executive  Director  
           353 W. 7th STREET, ROOM 103, ST. PAUL,  MN 55102     •      TEL (651) 287- 9999     •     W ww.MnTrades .org 
 
 
 
 
 upcoming projects and forcing the utility to spend more money chasing capital and less keeping 
rates affordable and service reliable.  
 We ask the Commission to make the right choice and approve the transaction, and we thank 
you for your time and consideration.  
 Best regards,  
 
 
 
Tom Dicklich  
Executive Director, Minnesota Building and Construction Trades Council

Commissioners,
 I’m writing regarding the proposed acquisition of ALLETE by Global Infrastructure Partners andCanadian Pension Plan Investment Board.  In listening to and reading other public comments thereappears to be a significant amount of misinformation and misconceptions about this sale.  
Commenters have cited concerns about local control of the utility.  The utility in its currentform has limited local control, of its ten-member Board of Directors, six of them reside outsideof Minnesota and nearly 74% of ALLETE shares are held by institutional investors.  As a whole,voting shareholders approved this transaction by a 97% margin on August 21, 2024.  Thecompany’s core function is to create shareholder profit by providing safe and reliable electricservice, this will be the case whether those shareholders are the current controlling majority ofinstitutional investors, or GIP and CPP. 
Commenters have given credit to Minnesota Power for their community involvement in thecommunities they serve, while also expressing concerns about whether those activities willcontinue.  As Minnesota Power’s community service and involvement are a function of themdoing business in those communities, it is likely this involvement will continue whether thecompany is owned by its current shareholders or GIP/CPP.  In addition, Minnesota Poweremployees will continue to work and live in the communities they serve.
Commenters have cited concerns about employees.  The company has been reducing staffthrough attrition for decades, particularly its unionized workforce.  IBEW Local 31 was able tonegotiate, and their membership approved a two-year extension of the existing laboragreement with reasonable wage increases, which would not have happened without thepending sale.  Many people have commented that there are no employment guaranteesbeyond the contract extension: this is completely true, just as it will also be true if thetransaction doesn’t go through, or if the extension didn’t happen.  Local 31 has had difficultnegotiations in the past and will likely have difficult negotiations in the future regardless ofwhether the company is owned by its current shareholders, or GIP/CPP.  Based on pastexperiences it isn’t the shareholders that have paid the price when the company has navigateddifficult financial times.  That burden was largely shouldered by employees and ultimatelyratepayers.  Employees in the form of layoffs, attrition, and reduced compensation andbenefits.  Ratepayers in the form of deferred infrastructure maintenance leading to highercosts later on, and service reliability issues. 
 
It is in everyone’s best interest to have a financially stable electric utility; this acquisition will provide
needed financial assurances to maintain existing infrastructure and service reliability.  For thesereasons, I am in support of the proposed transaction. Sincerely, Will KeyesCotton, MN

A longtime customer of Minnesota Power, I am strongly opposed to the sale of our local electric
company to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners. Providingelectrical power to the Twin Ports, Iron Range and North Shore communities is a necessary publicservice. And while those providing that service have a right to make a profit from doing so, thefarther away from Duluth ownership moves, the greater the chances the commitment to providingthis service gets overlooked in a push for higher profits or that the company becomes victim toneglect and a poorer quality of service is provided. Additionally, this community has a commitmenttoward sustainability that has been growing stronger and is just beginning to be reflected in theoperations of our local electric company. I believe this sale would endanger this bit of progress thathas been made.

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
Big private equity investors desire profits, that’s their only reason for being. This is inconsistent with the need to
provide Minnesota Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we allneed. Minnesotans have shown over and over again that we value clean water, air, and energy.
I am concerned because this sale would:
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information about
the company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
In fact, BlackRock oversees an enormous amount of shares in the fossil fuel industry and has a history of opposing
climate-related shareholder motions at these companies.
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Beth Hynes-CierniaMinneapolis, MN 55407-2207beth.hynesciernia@gmail.com

I am a customer of MN Power. I live in Duluth,MN and will be affected by the sale. 
I have many concerns regarding the sale of MN Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Boardand Global Infrastructure Partners, which is owned by BlackRock if it is allowed. 1. With everything that is happening with the tariffs and retaliation, selling our electric company to anon-US based firm is concerning. Living in a cold climate where electricity is essential for heat andsurvival it should be protected. 2. I lived in Alaska (am on the state’s Pioneer Registry) where I witnessed first hand the negativeenvironmental impacts of powerful large businesses for the sake of increased profit. Their promisesmeant nothing, the damage to the environment was done before it could be stopped and theenvironment will never be able to totally recover. Northern Minnesota has similar environmentalareas that we all need to protect. The world's biggest private equity firm, may value making moremoney over the environment. 3. During COVID, Canadian based company (PCL Construction) closed their Minnesota offices andlaid off the employees without notice, without a severance package and only 1 days notice ofinsurance coverage at a time when medical insurance was most needed. They did not supportMinnesota during COVID, why would we trust our electric utility to a non-US based company???Canada has different regulations than the US, how would our electricity be protected?Electricity is an essential utility that we do not have other options if they choose to raise rates orstop services, and should be protected. I hope the sale is stopped to protect our right to having an essential utility, electricity, whileprotecting the environment. Thank you,Lisa Brown

I am a current ALLETE, Inc. employee. 
After listening to the public hearings held during the week of 4/7 to 4/11/25, there seemed to be
two main recurring comments/concerns from individuals as well as intervenors about transparencyand rate increases. I think it is important for the commission to remember that even after theacquisition ALLETE will remain a regulated utility having to follow the current process of rateincreases through transparent rate cases as well as continuing to file numerous public reportsthroughout the year. ALLETE will still be required to file quarterly and audited annual FERC reports,the annual Minnesota Jurisdictional report, monthly and annual EIA-861 reports, and others. Theseare financial reports that ALLETE currently files and will continue to be required to file. 
Individuals and intervenors were also worried about rate increases, which is understandable no one
likes to pay more but with or without the acquisition there will be rate increases. Rate increaseswill happen regardless of the acquisition as ALLETE continues to invest in meeting the states 2040carbon free standard. allow ALLETE to make the needed infrastructure investments to meet the state's 2040 carbon freestandard while stile providing safe, reliable, and affordable electricity to their customers.

Re: Support for ALLETE Acquisition – MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24- 198  
 
Dear Commissioners,   
On behalf of the Minnesota Chamber of Commerce I am writing to express our support for 
the proposed acquisition of ALLETE, Inc., including its subsidiary Minnesota Power, by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP Investments) and the owners of Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), as outlined in Minnesota PUC Docket No. E015/PA -24- 198. 
We see potential in this transaction, particularly through the long -term investment 
commitment of  CPP Investments and GIP , while relying on the transparency and consumer 
protection provided by the Public Utilities Commission’s oversight.  
The involvement of CPP Investments and GIP signals a robust, long -term commitment to 
Minnesota Power’s future. These globally recognized investors bring substantial resources, ensuring access to the capital necessary to meet the state’s ambitious goal of 1 00% 
carbon-free electric generation while preserving grid reliability. This access to capital is critical for funding vital infrastructure projects, modernizing the grid, and expanding 
renewable energy initiatives —investments essential to supporting Minnes ota’s economic 
growth and environmental objectives.  
We recognize transparency ensured by the Public Utilities Commission’s oversight. 
ALLETE/Minnesota Power’s continued reporting to the PUC should maintain the 
accountability expected of an investor -owned utility, offering assurance that this 
acquisition aligns with the public good.   

 A key concern  for us, especially for i nvestor -owned utilities  given their large customer 
base , is energy affordab ility and reliability for commercial and industrial customers . These 
ratepayers —from small businesses to large manufacturers—are the backbone of our state 
and local economy, especially in regions like the Iron Range. Energy  costs and reliability 
directly inﬂuence jobs, competitiveness, and community vitality. The long -term investment 
from CPP and GIP could enhance Minnesota Power’s ability to deliver reliable electricity .  
We would ask  the Commission to consider and to ensure that the beneﬁts of this 
acquisition  will help to keep rates affordable  for commercial industrial ratepayers who 
comprise the majority of  customers in Minnesota Power’s service territory.  
Minnesota Power has a strong history of meeting the needs of their customers by sharing 
the Chamber goals of affordable , reliable , and cleaner energy. With the ﬁnancial backing 
and long -term vision of CPP Investments and GIP , coupled with the PUC’s transparent 
oversight, this acquisition could strengthen the utility’s capacity to meet growing energy 
demands sustainably. We trust the Commission will thor oughly assess these priorities to 
ensure the outcome beneﬁts all stakeholders.  
We believe that it is in the public interest to support this acquisition to ensure sufficient 
access to capital to meet the goals of reliable, affordable, and cleaner energy.  
Sincerely,   
 
Michelle Benson  
Minnesota Chamber of Commerce  
Director, Commerce and Utility Policy  
mbenson@mnchamber.com

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,

Minneapolis, MN 55406-1865

I am writing in strong opposition to the proposed sale of our power company to the Canada Pension
Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners, an entity owned by BlackRock.
Private equity firms are not public stewards. Their core obligation is to maximize short-term returns
for their investors, not to ensure long-term reliability, affordability, or equity in utility services.Across the country, we’ve seen what happens when public or quasi-public assets—especially utilities—fall into private equity hands: asset stripping, diminished services, rate hikes, and eventual resaleor closure. This business model undermines the stability and public accountability we rely on inessential services like electricity.
Utilities are not regular businesses; they are critical infrastructure. Minnesotans depend on
accessible, stable power—not speculative financial maneuvers designed to enrich billion-dollar firmsheadquartered far from the communities they serve. Allowing this sale would prioritize private profitover public interest.
Furthermore, the long-term risks of this acquisition include:
• Reduced investment in infrastructure and maintenance to increase margins• Rate increases passed on to consumers to satisfy return-on-equity demands• Loss of local control and transparency• Workforce reductions and outsourcing• Compromised climate and renewable energy goals
I urge the PUC to block this sale and preserve public oversight of our utility services. Minnesotans
deserve accountable, reliable energy—not another cautionary tale of private equity greed.

I would like to submit this for your consideration.
To Whom It May Concern:As former long-time employees of Allete/Minnesota Power, and as retirees who receive both a pension and medical
reimbursement from the company, we are writing to express our strong opposition to the proposed sale of Allete toGlobal Infrastructure Partners (GIP), a subsidiary of Blackrock, and the Canada Pension Plan Fund (CPP).
We are also current shareholders of Allete. However, if this deal is approved, all shareholders—ourselves included
—will be forced to sell our shares. We will have no choice in the matter. That alone is deeply concerning, as it stripsaway the voice and investment of long-time employees, retirees, and individuals who believe in the company’s long-term mission and its value to Minnesota communities.
This $6.2 billion sale is facing well-founded opposition from a diverse coalition of stakeholders, including consumer
advocates, the mining and wood products industries, and the Minnesota Department of Commerce. The concerns aresubstantial and credible: increased rates for customers, loss of local control, and a lack of transparency throughoutthe process.
GIP and CPP argue that they are better positioned to fund Allete’s renewable energy transition and infrastructure
needs. Yet testimony from financial and regulatory experts, including those representing the Minnesota Departmentof Commerce, disputes these claims. They cite a lack of evidence that the acquisition would improve access tocapital or benefit ratepayers in any meaningful way. In fact, the proposed transaction appears to pose significant riskof large rate increases, speculative investment strategies, and an erosion of public oversight.
Furthermore, we are disturbed by reports that GIP and CPP have avoided transparency during these proceedings—
refusing to answer questions fully, providing redacted responses, and limiting meaningful public engagement. This
lack of openness is not compatible with the trust and accountability required of a utility provider responsible forserving Minnesota homes and businesses.
Minnesota Power is more than a utility—it’s part of the fabric of the state and the communities it serves. It should
not be turned over to private equity interests with global portfolios and short-term profit motives. We urge theMinnesota Public Utilities Commission and all involved regulatory bodies to reject this acquisition and preserveAllete’s accountability to the public.
Sincerely,
Kim BuncichSent from my iPad

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commissioners,
 
I am writing to express my strong objections to the sale of Minnesota
Power to a private-equity buyer, and I urge you to reject the proposed
transaction on the grounds that it is NOT in the public interest. In fact,
given the track record of the would-be buyer, the transaction ­is likely to
be to the detriment of most, if not all, Minnesotans. 
 
As a Minnesota Power customer, I am concerned about the lack of
transparency that BlackRock and its acquisition partner have provided
about their intentions toward Minnesota ratepayers and the future of
the power company itself.  Since, as a private-equity company,
BlackRock—unlike Allete--has few public disclosure requirements, its
current lack of transparency is likely to become the new normal if it is
allowed to proceed with its proposed deal.  Moreover, the vague
“assurances” that the acquirers have made about the acquisition and its
effect on Minnesota ratepayers are virtually unenforceable because of
the ridiculously lax  regulatory regime that applies to private equity.
 
I also fear that Minnesota Power will be subject to the same strip-and-
flip business model that has made the public equity industry so rich and
so influential. The power company’s assets could easily be plundered by
BlackRock and it could end up back on the market again as a much
weaker company with far less recourse to capital markets than it has
now. That would indeed be ironic since its self-proclaimed difficulty in
raising capital, of which it has provided little evidence, is the shaky
rationale on which this proposed transaction has been constructed. 
 
In short, this acquisition is a bad deal for Minnesotans. I urge you to
reject it unequivocally. 
 
Beth Eastman

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Paul McHugh
Minneapolis, MN 55418-4229

To the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to express my wholehearted support for the acquisition of Minnesota Power. As alifelong Minnesotan who has personally navigated the complexities of selling my own company toenhance scalability and service delivery, I can attest to the transformative potential such transactionshold.
Local Perspective and Experience
Growing up in Minnesota, I have always valued the importance of community and the vital role thatlocal companies play in fostering economic growth and stability. My own journey in selling mybusiness was guided by a vision to strengthen our operations, expand our reach, and ultimatelyserve our customers more effectively. This experience has equipped me with a deep understandingof the positive impact that strategic acquisitions can have on a company's ability to innovate andprovide superior service.
Ensuring Better Service
The proposed sale and acquisition of Minnesota Power is a promising step towards achieving thesegoals. By leveraging the resources and expertise of the acquiring entity, Minnesota Power stands togain significant enhancements in infrastructure, technology, and operational efficiency. This, in turn,will translate into a more reliable and cost-effective service for Minnesotans across the state.
Economic and Environmental Benefits
Furthermore, the acquisition will likely spur economic development, creating job opportunities andstimulating local businesses. Additionally, it opens avenues for Minnesota Power to invest insustainable energy solutions, aligning with our state's commitment to environmental stewardshipand the pursuit of cleaner, greener energy sources.I strongly urge the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission to consider the myriad benefits thisacquisition presents. It is an opportunity to empower Minnesota Power to scale new heights inservice excellence, while fostering economic and environmental advancements that will benefit our
community for generations to come.
Thank you for your attention to this important matter. I am confident that with your support,
Minnesota Power can embark on a new chapter of growth and innovation, poised to serve our greatstate with even greater efficacy.Sincerely,
Josh Headlee

April 14, 2025
PUC Docket No. 24-198Regarding the acquisition of ALLETE and specifically Minnesota Power, by Blackrock and
Canadian Pension Plan, I am still opposed. 
I am almost 69 years old and have been a customer of MN Power for most of my life. I seldom
worry about economically efficient reliable power being delivered to my home. It is a joy tosee their crews out and about upgrading and maintaining the electrical infrastructure.  
Private equity groups such as Blackrock are notorious for selling off portions of their
acquisitions to make a quick buck. I fear that this will happen to MN Power and that will makethem less economically efficient. I also don’t expect that MN Power’s required carbonelimination goals will be met.
I also fear for the wages, benefits and safety of MN Power employees.Having attended the April 7, hearing at FDLTC in Cloquet, I was glad to hear that MN Power
and their workers have agreed to a contract into 2028.  During my 5 minutes, I asked therepresentative of Blackrock about the IBEW contract in 2029. He said that that would be up toMN Power. I was surprised by that because I assumed that since the shareholders of MP werebeing bought out, that there would not be a board and governance would be top down fromthe new owners.  So, I asked the representative of MN Power of who would appoint “theboard”.  She would not or could not answer that question.
The lack of transparency is worrisome.  I don’t have to know everything, but I do know that
Blackrock is not making this acquisition for egalitarian reasons. They are looking to profit andprobably a lot! I also know that our forbearers strived to make utilities affordable andresponsible, that the Public Utilities Commission works towards that end.
A lot of folks are expecting the MN Public Utilities Commission will be overseeing much of the
operation and that rate hikes will be kept down. Would the PUC have the time to oversee theoperations detail and ensure that efficiency was maintained? Will the PUC also be able to stop
Blackrock from selling off a valuable piece of property that keeps MN Power efficient?
I am going to suggest that if MN Power is going to be owned by a private group that it be
governed by a board elected from the ratepayers, one bill, one vote.  That board can choose amanager and should approve labor agreements and sales of assets.  This should be similar tothe way electric co-ops are run.
I realize that my suggestion might be audacious, but I am extremely annoyed at the lack of
transparency about this acquisition.
I don’t think that there would ever be a good time for this sale to be approved but given the
oligarchic biases of the current federal government, the ignoring and deregulation oflegitimate legislative safeguards and defunding oversight agencies, there could not possibly bea worse time for this sale be approved.
Sincerely,Mike Kuitu, 1114 W 6th St. Duluth,  MN 55806

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
We have to stop these moves toward privatization. They are not in the public interest.
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan InvestmentBoard (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Mehgan Blair
Duluth, MN 55811-9722mmb346@gmail.com

I hope that the acquisition of ALLETE by CPP and GIP will not go forward. 
My husband David and I attended the Monday evening, April 7, 2025 public hearing in Duluth
regarding the acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment (CPP) and GlobalInfrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock. We appreciated being able to listen tostatements from citizens on both sides of this acquisition and we appreciated your professionalismand courtesy to all of us present. We listened carefully from seats near the front, took a few notes,and went home to discuss our own reactions. During the week after this hearing, before my writtenresponse, I read about both CPP and GIP/BlackRock and my areas of concern were even moreheightened, particularly having to do with the latter.
I noticed at the hearing that most of the persons in favor of the acquisition were Minnesota
Power/ALLETE employees and labor union members. Their expectations of past and present jobsatisfaction and their trust in future employment under new ownership were reiterated. However,there are no guarantees in two short years that their job satisfaction or even their employment willcontinue. Local control over all their employment futures will be taken away. And losing local controlof our public utilities management could have serious and cascading effects upon our entire region,the LEAST of them being a (probably guaranteed) rise in electrical rates. I confess: alarm bells go offfor me. 
Various outside experts hired by the MN Department of Commerce and even the office of the
Attorney General are critical of this acquisition by two huge private companies, particularly GIP.Groups such as Sierra Club, CURE, CUB, individuals and shareholders have recommended that thePublic Utilities Commission reject the deal. Both CPP and GIP’s main argument for their acquisition isthat ALLETE’s goal of net-zero carbon emissions by 2040 can more easily be financially reached withthem. But neither partner is forthcoming about their real future goals. MY biggest concern is that inALLETE being owned by a private company, who knows what will happen? I have far more trust inpublic, information-sharing companies who have access to public markets. I would not mind ALLETE
being in a limited partnership with CPP. (I would like to see us teaming with our Canadian
neighbors.) I would prefer ALLETE expand its public shareholder base, rather than be absorbed by
the biggest profit entity in the world. (I would be willing to buy shares!) 
Do I trust GIP/BlackRock? No. I don’t, frankly. Why do they want to acquire ALLETE? I don’t believe
their goal is to help Minnesota achieve net-zero carbon emissions. I have been following this week’sstories about the Panama Canal, and BlackRock’s CEO, Larry Fink, who is determined to gain controlof Panama’s main ports. Perhaps BlackRock is more interested in the fact that we are a port, than inhelping with climate control. Maybe Fink is more interested in controlling ten percent of the world’sfresh water, or gaining mineral rights access. I do not trust this humongous, gobbling entity bent onprofit and power. 
I keep coming back to this: Potential risks to consumers and protectors of our lakes, our lands, our
waters, our grandchildren’s futures outweigh any potential benefits.
Lynn Tryggestad, 4101 Gladstone St., Duluth MN 55804, 218-341-7405

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
Big private equity investors desire profits, that’s their only reason for being. This is inconsistent with the need to
provide Minnesota Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we allneed. Minnesotans have shown over and over again that we value clean water, air, and energy.
I am concerned because this sale would:
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information about
the company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
In fact, BlackRock oversees an enormous amount of shares in the fossil fuel industry and has a history of opposing
climate-related shareholder motions at these companies.
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Beth Hynes-CierniaMinneapolis, MN 55407-2207beth.hynesciernia@gmail.com

To Whom It May Concern:
As former long-time employees of Allete/Minnesota Power, and as retirees who receive both a  
pension and medical reimbursement from the company, we are writing to express our strong  
opposition to the proposed sale of Allete to Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), a subsidiary of  
Blackrock, and the Canada Pension Plan Fund (CPP).
We are also current shareholders of Allete. However, if this deal is approved, all shareholders—
ourselves included—will be forced to sell our shares. We will have no choice in the matter. That  
alone is deeply concerning, as it strips away the voice and investment of long-time employees,  
retirees, and individuals who believe in the company’s long-term mission and its value to Minnesota  
communities.
This $6.2 billion sale is facing well-founded opposition from a diverse coalition of stakeholders,  
including consumer advocates, the mining and wood products industries, and the Minnesota  
Department of Commerce. The concerns are substantial and credible: increased rates for customers,  
loss of local control, and a lack of transparency throughout the process.
GIP and CPP argue that they are better positioned to fund Allete’s renewable energy transition and  
infrastructure needs. Yet testimony from financial and regulatory experts, including those  
representing the Minnesota Department of Commerce, disputes these claims. They cite a lack of  
evidence that the acquisition would improve access to capital or benefit ratepayers in any meaningful  
way. In fact, the proposed transaction appears to pose significant risk of large rate increases,  
speculative investment strategies, and an erosion of public oversight.Furthermore, we are disturbed by reports that GIP and CPP have avoided transparency during these  
proceedings—refusing to answer questions fully, providing redacted responses, and limiting  
meaningful public engagement. This lack of openness is not compatible with the trust and  
accountability required of a utility provider responsible for serving Minnesota homes and businesses.
Minnesota Power is more than a utility—it’s part of the fabric of the state and the communities it  
serves. It should not be turned over to private equity interests with global portfolios and short-term  
profit motives. We urge the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission and all involved regulatory  
bodies to reject this acquisition and preserve Allete’s accountability to the public.Sincerely,
Michele DeSmet

additional, and unnecessary burden.

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission:
Please remember that your duty as a commission is to protect the best interests of the PUBLIC, and
reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and GlobalInfrastructure Partners, owned by BlackRock, the world's biggest private equity firm. 
You don't have to be an economist or even do any research to see that private equity firms are
destroying countless public and private entities, scooping them up with their endless financialresources and sucking everything out of them to satisfy their stockholders, then discarding thoseonce thriving businesses. They are ONLY about making money from the money they already have,not serving the public.
Private equity firms are the leading cause of ridiculously overpriced housing, as they have been able
to pay above-market prices for single homes and apartment buildings, pricing out first-time homebuyers and low-income rental tenants. Then they resell the properties at hugely inflated prices toother private equity firms that have the same business model, endlessly hiking up inflation. Duluthhas already had a lot of negative impacts from this business model.
Private equity firms have nearly destroyed health care in many states; Florida, is an example, where
many of the health care systems are now for-profit, owned by private equity firms. I have witnessedthe diminished quality and accessibility of those for-profit health care systems. Health care shouldbe a right of every citizen, not a cash cow to be milked until there's no CARE involved, and then thebarn is burned down.
Currently, we have excellent service and reasonable pricing for our electricity in the Duluth area.
Because of private equity firms' exclusively profit-motivated business model, they are a terriblechoice to be the owners of PUBLIC utilities. And BlackRock is one of the most infamously successfulat applying that business model to every business.
Please find a better solution than selling our public utility to a private equity firm that is not
particularly interested in the generation and provision of electricity, nor likely to retain all of the
dedicated employees who risk their lives to rescue the public when we are left in the cold and
darkness.
Thank you for your thoughtful consideration of these important matters.
Sincerely,Sharon Becker
Duluth, MN

Infrastructure Partners (GIP). It's not consistent with the public interest.
This is bad for Minnesota because it:- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
Private Equity companies are solely about maximizing profits, and rarely if ever consider the public interest!  I am
writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board(CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest private equityfirm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
Sincerely,
Michelle Hensley
Minneapolis, MN 55406-2126mhensley@usfamily.net

To Whom It May Concern,
I am writing to express my strong opposition to the proposed sale of Minnesota Power to a private
equity firm.
This transaction would place a critical public utility-one that powers homes, businesses, and
essential services-into the hands of an entity whose sole purpose is financial gain. Private equityfirms are not accountable to the public. Their business model revolves around short-term profits,cost-cutting, and maximizing returns for investors, not long-term reliability, affordability, orcommunity well-being.
Allowing Minnesota Power to be sold to private equity risks higher energy prices, reduced
investment in grid resilience, and fewer commitments to sustainability. Residents of Minnesotadeserve a utility provider that prioritizes service reliability, clean energy innovation, and transparentpublic oversight-not one that treats electricity as just another asset in a financial portfolio.
Power is not a luxury. It is an essential service, and it should remain under the guidance of those
who understand and respect their obligation to the people of Minnesota-not Wall Street.
Please do not approve or support this sale. Our communities deserve better.

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to ask you to reject the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to the Canada Pension Plan Investment
Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock, the world’s biggest privateequity firm. This acquisition is not consistent with the public interest.
The interests of big private equity investors for outsized profits is inconsistent with the need to provide Minnesota
Power customers and communities with the affordable, reliable, clean, and safe electricity we all need. This is a baddeal for Minnesota because it:
- Risks saddling Minnesota ratepayers with higher electricity rates and less reliable and safe power service
- Undermines the long-term stability and operational continuity of an electric utility that serves a critical public
service
- Reduces public transparency and accountability by removing many requirements for disclosing information aboutthe company’s finances and business plans- Creates uncertainty in future employment for a large number of Minnesota Power’s employees- Puts Minnesota’s ability to meet its clean energy goals in the hands of far-off, wealthy investors who have myriadfossil fuel investments and have shown little commitment to cost-effective climate action
If this Commission is truly looking out for the best interests Minnesota Power customers, Minnesotans across the
state, and the public as a whole, it needs to reject the acquisition of ALLETE/Minnesota Power by the CanadaPension Plan Investment Board (CPP) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP).
